children.subject:
First off thanks! I tried my best to express that I sincerely want opinions and that I'm not just complaining lol. 

And to your response. I truly understand that and I agree. But what about this: 

  • For students you apply before entering berkeley (Incoming freshman or transfers): Make the selectivity higher, but they are accepted directly into the program
  • For students that are in Berkeley (Like as you said, finally discovered their path): Give them them the 3.3 cap. Maybe less than 3.3 or little more.

Issue with your first point:

1. Incoming freshmen may not have "discovered their path" -- if it's direct admittance into the program and 3.3 for nondirects, I'm not sure how that's going to solve the issue.

2. Admitted freshmen may not perform as well as other students who actually reach the 3.3 GPA cap -- admissions does not guarantee good grades.

1. Just to have the best of both worlds, give people more opportunities and just reduce the amount of stress put on students reaching for 3.3. But as the professor stated above, doing direct is not possible. 

2. This is inevitable, nothing is going to be perfect. The simple idea that someone doesn't do well as they should even though they are accepted into something spans from industry, clubs, education, social life, and many other areas of life. I feel like this is just a given. However, since Berkeley has a system of selecting great, successful students the probability of that happening is lower. Not perfect. But lower.
this is true for EECS as well, I know EECS students with below 3.3 in 61a, b and 70

You're post is very thoughtful! I'd love to chime in.

I think one of the main reasons that L&S CS does not follow the same procedures as EECS in that we restrict as the application level is that, in that case, there's would be no way to enter Berkeley CS after you've already been accepted and maybe have spent a semester here or more trying to discover what path you want to take.

history.content: If I had a say in the college committee, I would suggest using the procedure that Haas took in admitting business majors.

children.subject: Yeah, I don't think it's fair to just admit based on high school accomplishments. The most fair thing is to evaluate people on their performance and accomplishments in a college environment. GPA is not the end-all-be-all of that (e.g. many students have other responsibilities such as work, etc.) but it is a more fair line in the sand than basing things solely on high school. That being said, I do think that there could be some recognition of personal circumstance and situation rather than a hard cap.

> Yeah, I don't think it's fair to just admit based on high school accomplishments. The most fair thing is to evaluate people on their performance and accomplishments in a college environment.

I disagree with that cause I feel it's disadvantaged to people coming from disadvantaged backgrounds who want to be in tech. But I also see the argument that other disadvantaged students don't know they want to be in tech. In the end I think both systems are systemically unfair to some aspect of the population so it's good that both exist.

I'm the Anon that originally made this post. 

Nice, good stuff guys! I totally understand where you guys are getting at. However, I left out somethings: 

In addition to accepting students into CS, for the students that don't get accepted, give them their alternate major or undeclared status (so the same situation as now). 

Why this is good is because it allows everything that exists now (things that you guys mentioned above), but in addition to that, it allows those selected students the confidence that they will be in the major. And suppose that Berkeley decides to accept N number of people into the CS program. That is N more people that have the freedom to pursue their goals in comparison to now. For the other people that don't get direct admit just go through the same process as now. To me, the fact that N more people that get the chance to be directly admitted is an improvement.

There are so many ridiculously talented students here at Berkeley and can do amazing things. But the biggest phrase I hear is... "I'm just focusing on declaring right now."

Lets say like Berkeley was able to accept a few hundred directly into CS, while the others go into another major or undeclared (and work to declare into CS). 

Instead of those few hundred people saying: "I just want to declare." They will instead be saying: 

"I want to get a paper published" 

"I want to start making the next big thing in Tech" 

etc... etc. .. 

With the types of students we have at this school, we can do more than just focusing on a number.

Giving undeclared status to non-accepted CS-admit majors... wouldn't that increase the amount of people applying as they know undeclared is a safety? IMO, the type of people who say, "I want to get a paper published", "I want to start making the next big thing in Tech", either already have the capability to become CS majors by the current GPA cap, or know that life would be fine if they weren't able to make it into the major -- the real world is harsher.

Sidenote: I know we all say GPA is just a number, but some companies actually look at that as a signal.

Well, giving undeclared status to non-accepted CS-admit majors is essentially whats happening. Instead of undeclared, people just label it as "CS-intended". But really you can just come in and change it to any other major. 

Your statement is true. However, I also beleive that are there people who say "I want to get a paper published", who do have the ability to get something published, but couldn't make the cap. But that's a dumb debate we really don't need to dive into lol.

I think to really dive into my concerns is if we just take a step back and look at the big picture. It would be great that people don't stress about it too much and just know everything will be okay. But in reality, majority of the people do. More importantly, these people should know that they have the freedom to study what they want. Its interesting that we come here and 80% (okay, I get it this is a debatable number, but you get what I mean) of our focus is trying to declare and for transfer students it's legit 100% the focus. When ideally, students should be focusing on how they can just fully suck the nectar of berkeley's fruitful education. I just think it takes away from the experience a little.

I know people who got into MIT Masters and Berkeley's 5th year masters but wouldn't have made it into the major with the current GPA cap, how did they do it? Research, they worked on stuff they were passionate about rather than working on reaching a number for declaring... the current situation just makes me sad
I thought the 5th yearns master required a GPA of 3.5, or maybe that was the honors program.

It's a 3.0. It's possible to have below 3.3 on 61a, b and 70 and do better on upper divs when you take those that are aligned with your interests, also your grades in your later classes are better predictors for success in grad school than what you got on your lowerdivs.
If CS admissions is like EECS, many students will get outright rejected, including many who might be able to get 3.3+, or even 4.0, in the CS requirements.

history.content:
I think this is a very legitimate question, and concern. I share the same thoughts. However, in an educational environment constrained by economic and structural factors, I believe we just haven't found the right answer for accommodating the high demand for CS seats while meeting the academic and developmental needs of students. This may not answer your original question, or even provide consolation, but know that staff are grappling with this issue, too. We are hopeful that, with the input of students and by looking at real data, we can mediate these very complex issues in CS. 
I'm glad that you are sharing your thoughts through this forum.

---

While there are many pedagogical reasons why students aren't admitted directly into CS, I want to also point our that L&S does not admit any students directly into any major. There is also no mechanism in place for a department to do this.

I think this is a very legitimate question, and concern. I share the same thoughts. However, in an educational environment constrained by economic and structural factors, I believe we just haven't found the right answer for accommodating the high demand for CS seats while meeting the academic and developmental needs of students. This may not answer your original question, or even provide consolation, but know that staff are grappling with this issue, too. We are hopeful that, with the input of students and by looking at real data, we can mediate these very complex issues in CS. 
I'm glad that you are sharing your thoughts through this forum.

children.subject:
Well said. Completely agree. 

This is a bold statement, but I feel like we have student advocates for the 3.3 gap because of how intellectually talented the students here are. Berkeley is able to force such a high gpa on our students because for the majority test taking is their strength (Not me though!). But take this strategy to some other school's, they would have to quickly think of another idea because it would just end up bad - to say the least.

Personally I have been telling friends/family who ask me for CS advice not to choose Berkeley. This is with regard to individuals having no prior CS experience, primarily because of this 3.3 GPA cap.

3.3 is tough for someone who decides on CS in college with no prior experience going into 61A (I was premed originally). As OP stated, there are so many other aspects of college that need to be explored. If I had been held to a 3.3 cap, the anxiety and stress would be through the roof.

A new solution is certainly needed which maintains the program's prestige but also fosters a positive learning environment. I'm glad people are talking about the toxic negatives of this cap. 

You may disagree with my viewpoint and that's fine, but I'm an advocate for unexperienced potential CS majors--and of course--a less toxic environment where risk to students' mental health is mitigated. 

It's hard to learn when quite high standards (unrealistic for many) are put upon a student, given the holistic nature of college. Anxiety/stress (a prime instigator of depression) in Cal students is a problem, much more than people realize. Overall, my stance is a relatively high LSCS GPA cap diminishes overall learning.

history.content:
Whats up everyone, 

This topic is something I constantly ponder. I noticed that in this Piazza, many instructors were gladly able to respond to other students opinions, concerns, and questions. So I decided.. why not! 

So from a previous Piazza post, I read that the main reason why we have a 3.3 is that UC Berkeley doesn't have enough resources, both physically and financially, to accept everyone into the CS program. Then, why don't they follow the same thing as EECS: select students into the CS program, but since Berkeley doesn't have enough resources, just select less people into the CS program when they apply?

Personally (I might be able to speak for others as well), I have to give up a lot to shoot for this 3.3. And when I say give up, I don't mean gym, meals, social life.. etc. I dont care about that, thats a given when it comes to shooting for your dreams. What I mean are more important things - I have to temporarily give up CS clubs, my future start up plans, personal projects, etc. I'm pretty much postponing my life CS goals for a number. 

One of the biggest cookie coating support people give to others is: "It's okay, you can still get into google if you don't declare in". 

For me, and again I can probably speak for others too, CS is more than just a spot on a Big 4 CS company. I came out of HS with straight C's and CS helped me find direction in my life and academics. And after putting my heart and everything into it for these past years, someone is just going to tell me... go study something else that is "related"? So for the amount of work and sacrifice I did to get to where I am at now, I'm just going to let a number stop me from studying CS? You bet it won't. 

In summary, I just really believe there are better options than letting a number define someone's path and direction in life. I just really want to understand the thought processes of deciding on 3.3. What were the other solutions they were deciding on? 

Just to note: Thanks for reading this long post. I'm not mad/sad in anyway. I've been through worse, and I understand that this is life. But when I think about all the other students who are being prevented their freedom and passion of studying CS.. something just sparks in me. 

Thanks!
history.subject: Discussion on 3.3 GPA Cap: Was this really the best solution?
